item.title: Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 2028) to amend title 28, United States Code, with respect to the jurisdiction of Federal courts inferior to the Supreme Court over certain cases and controversies involving the Pledge of Allegiance.

latestAction.text: Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

item.text: Received in the Senate.
The title of the measure was amended. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 247 - 173 (Roll no. 467).
Passed/agreed to in House: On passage Passed by the Yeas and Nays: 247 - 173 (Roll no. 467).
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report H.R. 2028.

UNFINISHED BUSINESS - The Chair announced that the unfinished business was the question on adoption of the Watt amendment which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H.Res. 781, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Jackson-Lee amendment.

POSTPONED VOTE - At the conclusion of debate on the Watt amendment, the Chair put the question on adoption of the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Watt demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until later in the legislative day.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H.Res. 781, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 20 minutes of debate on the Watt amendment.
DEBATE - Pursuant to the provisions of H.Res. 781, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Sensenbrenner amendment.
GENERAL DEBATE - The Committee of the Whole proceeded with one hour of general debate on H.R. 2028.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mike Pence to act as Chairman of the Committee.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 781 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 2028 with 1 hour of general debate. Previous question shall be considered as ordered without intervening motions except motion to recommit with or without instructions. Measure will be considered read. Specified amendments are in order.
Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 781. (consideration: CR H7451-7478; text of measure as reported in House: CR H7470)
Rule H. Res. 781 passed House.

Rules Committee Resolution H. Res. 781 Reported to House. Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 2028 with 1 hour of general debate. Previous question shall be considered as ordered without intervening motions except motion to recommit with or without instructions. Measure will be considered read. Specified amendments are in order.
Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 424.
Reported (Amended) by the Committee on Judiciary. H. Rept. 108-691.
Reported (Amended) by the Committee on Judiciary. H. Rept. 108-691.
Ordered to be Reported (Amended) by the Yeas and Nays: 17 - 10.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.
Subcommittee on the Constitution Discharged.
Referred to the Subcommittee on the Constitution.
Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.
Introduced in House
Introduced in House

item.title: H.R. 2028, Pledge Protection Act of 2004
item.description: Cost estimate for the bill as ordered reported by the House Committee on the Judiciary on September 15, 2004

item.title: H.R. 2028, Pledge Protection Act of 2004
item.description: Cost estimate for the bill as ordered reported by the House Committee on the Judiciary on September 15, 2004

item.name: Civil Rights and Liberties, Minority Issues

summary.text: Pledge Protection Act of 2003 - Amends the Federal judicial code to deny jurisdiction to any court established by Act of Congress to hear or determine any claim that the recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance violates the first amendment of the Constitution.

Pledge Protection Act of 2004 - Amends the Federal judicial code to deny jurisdiction to any Federal court, and appellate jurisdiction to the Supreme Court, to hear or decide any question pertaining to the interpretation of the Pledge of Allegiance or its validity under the Constitution.

Pledge Protection Act of 2004 - Amends the Federal judicial code to deny jurisdiction to any Federal court, and appellate jurisdiction to the Supreme Court, to hear or decide any question pertaining to the interpretation of the Pledge of Allegiance or its validity under the Constitution. Makes this limitation inapplicable to the Superior Court of the District of Columbia or the District of Columbia Court of Appeals.

item.title: To amend title 28, United States Code, with respect to the jurisdiction of Federal courts inferior to the Supreme Court over certain cases and controversies involving the Pledge of Allegiance.

item.titleType: Official Titles as Amended by House
item.title: To amend title 28, United States Code, with respect to the jurisdiction of Federal courts over certain cases and controversies involving the Pledge of Allegiance.

item.titleType: Short Titles as Reported to House
item.title: Pledge Protection Act of 2004

amendment.description: Amendment sought to provide an exception to the preclusion provisions of the bill for instances alleging coerced or madatory recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance in violation of the First Amendment.
amendment.purpose: An amendment numbered three printed in House Report 108-693 to insert the following after "recitation" in section 1632 of title 28, United States Code, as added by section 2(a) of the bill: ", except in a case in which the claim involved alleges coerced or mandatory recitation of the Pledge of Allegiance, including coercion in violation of the protection of the free exercise of religion, such as that held to be in violation of the First Amendment in West Virginia State Board of Education v. Barnett, 319 U.S. 624, 638 (1943) and Circle School v. Pappert (No. 03-3285; 3rd Circuit, August 19, 2004)".

latestAction.text: On agreeing to the Jackson-Lee (TX) amendment (A003) Failed by voice vote.

item.text: On agreeing to the Jackson-Lee (TX) amendment (A003) Failed by voice vote.
Amendment (A003) offered by Ms. Jackson-Lee (TX). (consideration: CR H7475-7477; text: CR H7475)
House amendment offered/reported by : Amendment (A003) offered by Ms. Jackson-Lee (TX).(consideration: CR H7475-7477; text: CR H7475)
Amendment failed in Committee of the Whole
House amendment not agreed to: On agreeing to the Jackson-Lee (TX) amendment (A003) Failed by voice vote.
House amendment offered

amendment.description: Amendment sought to preserve Supreme Court review of appeals related to the constitutionality of the Pledge of Allegiance.
amendment.purpose: An amendment numbered two printed in House Report 108-693 to strike the following in section 1632 of title 28, United States Code, as added by section 2(a) of the bill: ", and the Supreme Court shall have no appellate jurisdiction,".

latestAction.text: On agreeing to the Watt amendment (A002) Failed by recorded vote: 202 - 217 (Roll no. 466).

item.text: On agreeing to the Watt amendment (A002) Failed by recorded vote: 202 - 217 (Roll no. 466).
Amendment (A002) offered by Mr. Watt. (consideration: CR H7472-7475, H7477; text: CR H7472)
House amendment offered/reported by : Amendment (A002) offered by Mr. Watt.(consideration: CR H7472-7475, H7477; text: CR H7472)
House amendment not agreed to: On agreeing to the Watt amendment (A002) Failed by recorded vote: 202 - 217 (Roll no. 466).
Amendment failed in Committee of the Whole
Roll call votes on amendments in House
House amendment offered

amendment.description: Amendment clarifies that the local courts of the District of Columbia may consider cases relating to the Pledge of Allegiance.
amendment.purpose: An amendment numbered one printed in House Report 108-693 to insert the following in section 1632 of title 28, United States Code, as added by section 2(a) of the bill: "The limitation in this section shall not apply to the Superior Court of the District of Columbia or the District of Columbia Court of Appeals.".

latestAction.text: On agreeing to the Sensenbrenner amendment (A001) Agreed to by voice vote.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
